head.title: Deukmejian Names 3 To State Supreme Court

hedline.hl1: Deukmejian Names 3 To State Supreme Court

LEAD: Gov. George Deukmejian selected three new justices for the California Supreme Court today, heralding the end of a decade of liberal dominance of the court.
Gov. George Deukmejian selected three new justices for the California Supreme Court today, heralding the end of a decade of liberal dominance of the court.

The nominations, if confirmed by the state Commission on Judicial Appointments, would bring to five the number of Supreme Court appointments the Republican Governor has made, giving him a decisive majority on the seven-member court. A hearing has been set for March 18.

The Governor named John A. Arguelles, 59 years old, of Irvine, David N. Eagleson, 62, of Long Beach, and Marcus M. Kaufman, 57, of San Bernardino, all state appeals court judges, to the Supreme Court.
Judges Arguelles and Eagleson had been appointed by Mr. Deukmejian to the appeals court bench; Judge Kaufman had been named by Ronald Reagan when he was Governor.
''In making these appointments, I have turned to justices who are known for their intergity, balance, intellectual capability and extensive legal experience,'' the Governor said in a statement.
Earlier, Governor Deukmejian appointed his former law partner, Malcolm Lucas, as chief justice and named Edward Panelli as an associate justice.
